skill.name: planning-sprints
skill.description: Provides comprehensive sprint planning expertise using agile best practices. Helps teams plan sprints, prioritize backlogs, calculate capacity, track velocity, and facilitate retrospectives.
skill.summary: Expert agile sprint planning assistant for scrum teams
skill.author: C0ntr0lledCha0s

security_audit.summary: Static analysis detected 81 potential issues, but all are false positives. The external command patterns are legitimate documentation examples showing bash commands for GitHub CLI operations. The weak cryptographic algorithm alerts are triggered by markdown code blocks containing placeholder text that matches pattern detection. No actual executable code or security vulnerabilities exist in this documentation-only skill.

low_findings.title: Documentation contains command examples
low_findings.description: The skill documentation includes markdown code blocks with examples of bash commands (gh CLI, python scripts) that users might execute. These are instructional examples, not executable code within the skill itself. The skill is documentation-only with no executable scripts.

content.user_title: Plan agile sprints with expert guidance
content.value_statement: Sprint planning is complex and time consuming when done manually. This skill automates sprint planning with best practices from agile methodology, helping teams prioritize backlogs, calculate capacity, track velocity, and create comprehensive sprint plans.
actual_capabilities: Facilitate comprehensive sprint planning sessions with capacity calculations
Apply prioritization frameworks including RICE, MoSCoW, WSJF, and Value vs Effort
Calculate historical velocity and track team capacity over time
Generate structured sprint plans using best practice templates
Monitor sprint progress and identify scope creep or blockers
Facilitate retrospective sessions with actionable improvement items
limitations: Does not directly integrate with project management tools or APIs
Requires manual input of team capacity and historical velocity data
Cannot automatically execute GitHub CLI commands shown in examples
Templates and scripts referenced in documentation are not included

use_cases.title: Plan a new sprint for development team
use_cases.description: A scrum master can use this skill to plan Sprint 6 by analyzing the backlog, calculating team capacity based on availability, applying RICE scoring to prioritize issues, and creating a comprehensive sprint plan document with clear goals and success criteria.
use_cases.target_user: Scrum masters and agile team leads

use_cases.title: Prioritize product backlog with scoring
use_cases.description: Product managers can apply multiple prioritization frameworks to score and rank backlog items by reach, impact, confidence, and effort. The skill helps identify quick wins versus long term investments and creates a prioritized roadmap.

use_cases.title: Monitor sprint progress and adjust scope
use_cases.description: Teams can check mid-sprint progress by analyzing burndown metrics, identifying blockers, and receiving recommendations for scope adjustments when the sprint is tracking behind schedule.

prompt_templates.title: Calculate team velocity
prompt_templates.prompt: Calculate our team velocity based on the last 5 sprints and recommend capacity for upcoming sprint

prompt_templates.title: Check sprint progress

best_practices: Keep sprints time boxed to 1 to 2 weeks and use 80 percent of calculated capacity to avoid overcommitment
Define one clear sprint goal rather than a collection of unrelated tasks and ensure all selected items align with that goal
Calculate velocity using a 3 to 5 sprint average and account for team changes or capacity variations
anti_patterns: Adding work mid sprint without removing something else creates scope creep and breaks team focus
Overcommitting by taking more story points than historical velocity consistently leads to incomplete sprints
Skipping retrospectives means missing opportunities to identify and fix process problems

faq.question: What prioritization framework should I use?
faq.answer: Use RICE scoring for product features, MoSCoW for release planning, and Value vs Effort matrix for quick visual prioritization. RICE is recommended as the default framework for most backlog prioritization tasks.

faq.question: How do I calculate team capacity for a sprint?
faq.answer: Multiply team size by sprint days by 5 to 6 productive hours per day. Then subtract time for meetings, PTO, holidays, and other commitments. Use 80 percent of this effective capacity for sprint commitment.

faq.question: What is a good sprint velocity?
faq.answer: There is no universal good velocity because each team defines story points differently. Focus on consistency within your team and aim for a completion rate above 90 percent of committed points.

faq.question: How many story points should be in a sprint?
faq.answer: Use your team historical velocity average from the last 3 to 5 sprints as the baseline. Commit to 80 percent of your calculated capacity to allow buffer for unknowns and urgent work.

faq.question: What if we are behind schedule mid sprint?
faq.answer: Identify blockers first and try to remove them. If still behind, descope lower priority items with stakeholder approval to protect the sprint goal. Avoid extending the sprint duration.

faq.question: Does this skill execute commands automatically?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidance and documentation with command examples. Users must manually execute any GitHub CLI commands or scripts shown in the planning process.
